review.title: Spaceprint: a Mobility-based Fingerprinting Scheme for Public Spaces
review.abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of how automated situation-awareness can be achieved by learning real-world situations from ubiquitously generated mobility data. Without semantic input about the time and space where situations take place, this turns out to be a fundamental challenging problem. Uncertainties also introduce technical challenges when data is generated in irregular time intervals, being mixed with noise, and errors. Purely relying on temporal patterns observable in mobility data, in this paper, we propose Spaceprint, a fully automated algorithm for finding the repetitive pattern of similar situations in spaces. We evaluate this technique by showing how the latent variables describing the category, and the actual identity of a space can be discovered from the extracted situation patterns. Doing so, we use different real-world mobility datasets with data about the presence of mobile entities in a variety of spaces. We also evaluate the performance of this technique by showing its robustness against uncertainties.

metadata.title: Spaceprint: a Mobility-based Fingerprinting Scheme for Public Spaces

sections.text: In this paper, we propose Spaceprint, a fully automated algorithm for recording repetitive situations in rooms. We evaluate this technique by showing how the latent variables describing the category and the actual identity of a room can be discovered from the extracted situation, using various real mobility data sets with data on the presence of mobile units in a variety of rooms. We also evaluate the performance of this technique by demonstrating its robustness to uncertainties. KEYWORDS Spatial Proling, WiFi scanning, spatio-temporal analysis, mining mobility, Point of Interest Classi cationACM Reference format: Mitra Baratchi, Geert Heijenk, Maarten van Steen.

sections.heading: 3 PROBLEM DEFINITION
sections.text: We have a model that is based on data from any system that enables the collection of mobility data relating to the presence or detection of mobile units in an affluent space region. The detection record is a tuple < d, s, t >, where d is the identification of the detected mobile object, where s is the identification of the space in which the object was detected d, and t is the time stamp of the detection. A variety of detection systems for mobility data can lead to such a dataset, including, for example, WiFi detection of mobile devices near access points, GPS coordinates discredited in grid maps, and check-in records collected from location-based social networks.Given a number of detection records DT, we are interested in a spatial Ngerprint SP (s) that represents the core of repetitive temporal presence of rooms. Assuming that we have latent manageable space with a unique spatial identity and pressure pattern, we have a spatial identity similar to that of space 1.

sections.heading: 5 METHODOLOGY
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Presence patterns
sections.text: As already mentioned, the most important step in ngerting spaces is the identification of suitable (predictable) characteristics that represent the situation in rooms. Consider the selection of characteristics that can be relevant for such a purpose and can be observed by mobility data. For example, one can intuitively think of static characteristics such as opening or closing times, peak hours, group sizes, number of people, etc. However, characteristics that can capture the situation in a room are numerous and intuitively associated with a comprehensive set of characteristics that could characterize every conceivable situation in rooms are practically impossible. Without intuitive assumptions about characteristics that can capture the situation in a room, the only measurable feature of captures is associated with the presence of mobile entities. In fact, each room considers many of these characteristics that form due to the diversity of the intention of its visitors. For example, we consider the presence of shopkeepers in a shop against that of their customers.

sections.heading: 5.2 Feature vector
sections.text: As already mentioned, the presence of features can be generated by counting mobile entities on the basis of any possible combination of start time, dwell time, and sampling time. < F = FR = FR = Sampling period, tstart, τ, Ts. Considering that we have all possible combinations by ranking over these parameters, we will have an n-dimensional vector composed of the existing features. Algorithm 2 (vectorize) represents the way we build a feature vector for a given space, based on a collection of mobile entity detectors.e Input of this algorithm is a set of proofs DT (s) for a spectral space. If we are a permanent window, we write DT [W] to name the subset of proofs that occurred within W. If Ts is a sampling time, then [Dmin Ts] denotes the Tmax list (T − T).

sections.heading: 5.3 Fingerprint parameters
sections.text: We are now focusing on appropriate values for the minimum traffic light duration FD and the number of detailed resolutions FR. Regarding the ngerprint duration, it should be noted that we are looking for the period (in the formal sense) of a repetitive or self-similar situation. There are many ways to do this, for example by Fourier analysis or computerized autocorrelations. In our approach, we are looking for a series of consecutive time windows W1, W2, W3, so that for a given set of discoveries DT we have a minimum cumulative distance between all possible pairs of vectorized subsets of discoveries DT [Wi] and DT [Wj]. Our only variable is the length of all such windows, and the length that minimizes the accumulated distance is our ngerprint element. Determining the best ngerprint resolution is a bit tricky. e resolution as shown in Algorithm 2 determines the number of detailed resolutions.

sections.heading: 6 EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section we show how room category vectors can be used to repeat repetitive situations in rooms. We also evaluate the performance of room categories in the presence of uncertainties. Assessment Approach: We expect the ngerprint of situations in a room to be extracted from what and what kind of room it is. Therefore, we evaluate our method to see how the latent variables of the semantic category of a room and its unique identity can be reflected in the ngerprint of the room. Our ratings are based on the use of feature vectors previously mentioned in unattended class categories to derive these latent variables. sections.heading: 6.2 Real datasets
sections.text: In this section, we apply our ngerprinting framework to two sets of data originating from the real world public space. Both sets of data correspond to our model in Section 3. However, because they have different data collection mechanisms, they exhibit subtle differences in terms of the scarcity of detections and the diversity of spaces (summarized in Table 3.) The first set of data consists of a series of WiFi detections that are very rich in the number of detections collected per room, but contain data from a limited number of rooms. is the data set collected by WiFi scanners located in all corners of our campus for a period of 5 months. and the second set, which is a data set from Foursquare [19] check-ins, is very diverse in terms of the number of detections available per site, but much more economical. We selected locations within the top 100 site categories with data from more than 531 days.

sections.heading: 6.3 Case study with WiFi dataset
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 6.4 Case study with the Foursquare dataset
sections.text: In this section, we perform evaluations based on a data set collected by Foursquare on location in social networks. Each room in this data set has a white space ID and a white space category. Taking each of these two labels as the reason for determining cluster performance, gives us the ability to perform two types of values. e rst one, similar to ratings on the WiFi record, is to classify feature vectors to know from which room they were extracted. e second, there is the ability to classify feature vectors of a group of rooms to know from what kind of space they were collected. e performance is based on classifications of rooms with category labels such as home, o ce, airport, restaurant, Chinese restaurant, street etc. (full list is designated due to lack of space).6.4.1 Clustering performance (latent variable of identity). For the experiment, the performance is based on clusters of rooms, such as airport, the performance is performed with categories.

sections.heading: 7 DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced Spaceprint, a technique for creating spatial imprints for repetitive situations in public spaces. What makes Spaceprint unique is its fully automated operation with minimal input from anyone who operates it. Our evaluations show that automatic printing of rooms is actually possible, paving the way for more complex approaches to automated situation capture. We also conclude that Spaceprint is relatively insensitive to parameters that can affect the accuracy of classification. By automatically extracting Ngerprint parameters, Spaceprint enables the design embedding of privacy in data capture by anonymizing data (e.g. by hashing) with timely hashes based on Ngerprint duration parameters, so that the accuracy of the spatial Ngerprint does not matter either. In this paper, we explored the possibility of generating repetitive situations in a single room.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we address the problem of how automated situationawareness can be achieved by learning real-world situations from ubiquitously generated mobility data. Without semantic input about the time and space where situations take place, this turns out to be a fundamental challenging problem. Uncertainties also introduce technical challenges when data is generated in irregular time intervals, being mixed with noise, and errors. Purely relying on temporal paerns observable in mobility data, in this paper, we propose Spaceprint, a fully automated algorithm for nding the repetitive paern of similar situations in spaces. We evaluate this technique by showing how the latent variables describing the category, and the actual identity of a space can be discovered from the extracted situation paerns. Doing so, we use dierent real-world mobility datasets with data about the presence of mobile entities in a variety of spaces. We also evaluate the performance of this technique by showing its robustness against uncertainties.
